translation.en: [woman] Ladies and gentlemen, the Honorable Justice Ginsburg.
"I hereby declare, on oath..."
[crowd] I hereby declare, on oath.
[Ginsburg] "...I will support and defend the Constitution..."
[crowd] I will support and defend the Constitution.
"...against all enemies..."
[crowd] Against all enemies.
"...foreign and domestic."
[crowd] Foreign and domestic.
[Ginsburg] "That I will bear arms..."
That I will bear arms.
"...on behalf of the United States..."
[crowd] On behalf of the United States.
"...when required by law."
[crowd] When required by law.
[Ginsburg] After the words,
"We the people of the United States,"
the Constitution sets out the aspiration
to form a more perfect union.
We abolished slavery, prohibited racial discrimination,
translation.ko: 우린 노예제를 종식하고 인종 차별을 철폐하였으며

translation.en: and made men and women people of equal citizenship stature...
translation.ko: 남자와 여자에게 동등한 시민 지위를 부여함으로써

translation.en: making ever more vibrant
our national motto...
E pluribus unum,
"Out of Many, One."
[woman] All right, everybody, uh, good morning.
[group] Good morning.
[woman] Nice to see you all.
My name is Samantha Rijkers, and I am originally from the Netherlands.
When I started this job, I just felt so excited
translation.ko: 이 일을 맡게 돼 정말로 기뻤어요

translation.en: that I could help fellow immigrants also become citizens.
translation.ko: 동료 이민자가 저처럼 시민이 되게 도울 수 있어서요

translation.en: [Rijkers] Since we are going to be spending a lot of time together,
translation.ko: 앞으로 많은 시간을 함께 보내게 될 테니

translation.en: I always think it's nice for all of us to get to know each other a little bit.
translation.ko: 서로에 대해 조금이라도 알게 되면 좋을 것 같아요

translation.en: All right.
-Who's ready to go first? -[group chuckles]
[woman] My name is Dipna,
I'm from Mexico,
-like my blouse. -[Dipna and group laugh]
I came here since 1989, so do the math.
translation.ko: 1989년에 왔으니 여기 산 지도 꽤 오래됐죠

translation.en: I want to apply for a citizenship
because we came for better opportunities,
for freedom.
Things are changing,
something can happen with only the residence.
translation.ko: 영주권이 있더라도 무슨 일이 생길지 모르니

translation.en: We have to become a citizens,
that's why.
I came here to United States in 2012.
I was granted political asylum
because I was suffering persecution from the Venezuelan government.
And I would like to become citizen.
For two reasons.
First of all,
because I think, uh...
this is the way to say thank you...
to this wonderful country.
And second,
because I love democracy and liberty.
[woman] I'm from Colombia.
I've been here about 21 years.
I come because I fell in love with him, my husband.
translation.ko: 이곳에 온 건 남편을 사랑했기 때문이죠

translation.en: And, you know, it's time to be a citizen,
translation.ko: 이젠 시민이 될 때인 것 같아요 "다고베르토 아리스티사발"

translation.en: because we love this country and we are scared about the future.
We want to be a part of the citizen,
so the next time we can vote.
We can have the rights. We can have the voice.
We can count.
[man] I want to become US citizen
because I much appreciate freedom.
There is no freedom in China,
and people are also suffering there.
If you say something, you will suffer some persecutions.
Here, we can spread the freedom to-- to-- to other place.
translation.ko: 여기선 자유를 다른 곳에 퍼트릴 수 있죠

translation.en: That's why I want to become American citizen here.
-Yeah, that's why. -[Rijkers] Thank you.
[Rijkers] Follow me. We're going to our first painting.
What did you notice?
If you want to pass the citizenship test,
immigrants have to study 100 questions
about American history and government, and they will be asked
up to ten of those.
They have to answer six correctly to pass.
Native Americans,
soldiers...
There's soldiers also in the back.
Those questions are about history, civics.
translation.ko: 그 질문들은 역사와 시민 윤리에 관한 것인데

translation.en: They have to understand how the US government works.
translation.ko: 미국 정부의 작동 방식을 이해해야 해요

translation.en: And for people who did not grow up in this country,
who did not go to school in this country,
that is very challenging.
Who are the different people in this painting?
And the other group...
How can we study history using paintings and artifacts?
translation.ko: 어떻게 그림과 유물로 역사를 공부할 수 있을까요?

translation.en: What do you see in this painting?
[woman] It's winter.
-[Rijkers] How do you know it's winter? -[woman] It's snowy.
[woman 2] And there's guns.
[Rijkers] Guns. What else?
-[woman] Families, children, babies. -Yeah.
[woman 2] They're guiding them to somewhere.
-[Rijkers] They're going somewhere. -[woman] Church.
How do you know they're going to church?
-Well, because of the pastors. -[woman] The priest.
[Rijkers] What is the family carrying?
-[woman] Books. -[Rijkers] Books.
-Probably Bibles. -[group] Bibles.
-[woman] Yes. -[woman 2] They're looking for something.
Yeah. What-- What could they be looking for?
[woman] Like, for a place?
Mm-hmm. Somewhere to go?
[woman] Maybe they're taking them to a place of safety.
Maybe it's unsafe. What could be the danger?
Maybe they're coming back from...
participating in some sort of religious...
-[woman] Event. -...event, yeah.
[Rijkers] So,
it is dangerous for them to go.
So if they're going to church
and it is dangerous,
what does that tell us about these people?
[woman] They're not able to freely demonstrate their religion.
This painting is called Pilgrims Going to Church.
And they came here for freedom.
But specifically, freedom of religion. All right?
translation.ko: 특히 종교의 자유를 찾아서 온 거예요

translation.en: And that's what we can see here.
[woman] What kind of question do they ask,
you know, in the 100 questions that will be related to this painting?
[Rijkers] What is one reason colonists came to America?
translation.ko: 식민지 개척자들이 미국에 온 이유가 뭐죠?

translation.en: -Religion. -[woman] Freedom, religion...
[Rijkers] Okay.
Already know one of the 100 questions. Right? We're good to go.
translation.ko: 벌써 100개 중 하나를 아시네요 잘하고 계세요

translation.en: [woman] This is a time of great insecurity for many immigrants in our nation.
translation.ko: 지금은 미국의 이민자들에게 몹시 불안한 시기입니다

translation.en: Even for lawful permanent residents like many of you.
[woman] Can you tell me how is it that you got your green card?
Did they do that in the office,
or did you have to go to the court?
Court, ma'am, in the court.
One of the things that's great about becoming a US citizen
translation.ko: 미국 시민이 되면 좋은 점 중 하나는

translation.en: is that it gives you a certain amount of freedom.
Once you become a citizen, they can't take it away from you.
translation.ko: 시민이 되고 나면 그걸 뺏길 수 없어요

translation.en: [Dipna, in Spanish] Having citizenship is important
because of all the insecurity we're going through at the moment.
translation.ko: 지금은 이민자들에게 무슨 일이 생길지 몰라요

translation.en: [in English] Can you read, write, and speak basic English?
translation.ko: 기초적인 영어를 읽고 쓰고 말할 수 있나요?

translation.en: -Yeah, I can write, I can read. -Very good.
translation.ko: - 네, 읽고 쓸 수 있어요 - 좋습니다

translation.en: [in Spanish] An immigrant is someone who comes to contribute to the country.
translation.ko: 이민자는 이 나라에 기여하기 위해 온 사람이에요

translation.en: [woman, in English] Have you ever been ordered, removed,
translation.ko: 미국에서 출국당하거나 입국이 거절되거나 추방된 적이 있습니까?

translation.en: excluded or deported from the United States?
[Alexandra, in Spanish] The immigration situation is getting harder.
And the stuff we are being told is starting to scare us.
translation.ko: 주변에서 들리는 얘기가 우리를 두렵게 했죠

translation.en: [in English] Have you ever had any kind of military or weapons training?
[Dipna, in Spanish] When I was able to file the papers for my residency,
translation.ko: 영주권을 얻기 위한 서류를 제출할 수 있었을 때

translation.en: my children were very happy,
because it assured us
that we would be able to stick together.
[in English] Are you willing to bear arms on behalf of the United States?
translation.ko: 미국을 위해 무기를 들 수 있습니까?

translation.en: Yes.
[in Spanish] All immigrants are in pursuit of happiness.
[woman, in English] If law requires it, are you willing to perform...
[Zhang, in Chinese] I think my greatest happiness is that I could come to America
and become an American citizen.
translation.ko: 미국에 온 것과 미국 시민이 된 겁니다

translation.en: [Rijkers, in English] Look at the painting.
What did you notice?
[woman] People getting hurt...
[woman 2] Yeah, they tried to, like, take down the horse...
[Rijkers] It's a horse. What else can you tell about the statue?
[man] The king. Right?
-How do you know it's a king? -[man] The crown.
translation.ko: - 왕인 줄 어떻게 알죠? - 왕관을 썼어요

translation.en: [Rijkers] The crown, right?
Yeah, it's King George III of England.
So, on July 9th of 1776,
the Declaration of Independence reached New York City.
It took five days for news to travel from Philadelphia,
where it was written, to New York.
They got so excited,
a small group of George Washington's soldiers
ran down to the statue of King George III.
When they got to the statue, they started pulling it down.
If you look up, you can see
that's the real statue's horse's tail that survived.
translation.ko: 지금까지 살아남은 저 동상의 말 꼬리가 있어요

translation.en: -[group] Oh! -[Rijkers] It's right up there.
So, let's bring it back to the test.
translation.ko: 그럼 이와 관련된 시험 문제를 맞혀보죠

translation.en: When was the Declaration of Independence adopted?
-July. -[woman] July 4th.
It's July 4th, but it took until July 9th
for people in New York City to find out about it.
So the answer is July 4th, 1776.
This is what it would have sounded like
if you were at the Common on July 9th, 1776.
translation.ko: 공원에 있었다면 이런 말을 들었을 겁니다

translation.en: "We hold these truths to be self-evident,
translation.ko: '우린 다음과 같은 진리를 자명한 것으로 받아들인다'

translation.en: that all men are created equal,
that they are endowed by their Creator with certain unalienable Rights,
translation.ko: '창조자에게 부여받은 양도할 수 없는 권리를 지녔다'

translation.en: that among these are Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Happiness."
[Zhang, in Chinese] Human beings are not willing to live in a locked-up space.
translation.ko: 인간은 갇혀서 사는 걸 원하지 않습니다

translation.en: They aspire to live in a free terrain.
They aspire to have, for example, the right to religion,
translation.ko: 종교의 자유를 열망하고 표현의 자유를 열망하고

translation.en: the right to expression, the right to freedom.
And the right to live in an unrestrained environment.
translation.ko: 속박이 없는 환경에서 살아갈 권리를 열망하죠

translation.en: A poem goes like this,
“Life is dear, love is dearer.
Both can be given up for freedom.”
translation.ko: '하지만 둘 다 자유를 대신할 수 없다'

translation.en: Freedom is a person’s highest pursuit.
translation.ko: 자유는 인간이 추구하는 가장 고귀한 이상입니다

translation.en: [Dagoberto, in Spanish] I had a tourist visa. At that time, they didn’t bother me.
translation.ko: 전 관광 비자가 있었고 그땐 그게 문제가 안 됐어요

translation.en: I’d come, stay with my sister for a while.
translation.ko: 누이 집을 방문해 한동안 머물곤 했죠

translation.en: At the time, getting a visa was a possibility,
so I’d come over.
In 2001, after the Twin Towers incident,
translation.ko: 하지만 9.11 테러로 무역 센터가 무너진 후

translation.en: that all stopped.
They became stricter with immigration laws.
So I thought, "I’m not going back anymore."
[Alexandra] I didn’t know how hard it was to emigrate.
Because it’s not just about moving.
It’s a different language and culture,
lots of things to learn.
We went to the lawyer’s office.
That case cost us some 30,000 dollars,
because they announced in the news that the immigration fees were going up.
translation.ko: 뉴스에서 이민 비용이 올라간다는 얘기가 나와서

translation.en: They took advantage of us.
And to make matters worse,
its founder went to prison
and everything went backwards.
So we had to start all over and pay fees to yet another attorney to be represented,
translation.ko: 처음부터 다시 시작해야 했고 다른 변호사를 고용해야 했어요

translation.en: new fees to file the paperwork.
translation.ko: 서류 비용도 한 번 더 내야 했고요

translation.en: It was a slow and difficult process to get our papers.
translation.ko: 서류 준비 과정은 무척 느리고 어려웠어요

translation.en: You come here, you get settled,
you learn to love this country, you get used to it,
translation.ko: 이곳에 익숙해졌고 이 나라를 사랑하게 됐어요

translation.en: you put down roots here, have a son.
[Dagoberto] It’s been many years. We’ve been here for 30 years.
[Alexandra] It’s been a whole life. Half of our lives here.
To become a citizen, you need...
to love this country, and we do.
We’re Colombians, but we feel like we’re from here.
translation.ko: 우린 콜롬비아인이지만 이곳에서 태어난 것 같아요

translation.en: Half of our life is here.
We’ve contributed
and we’ve done things how they should be done.
-[woman, in English] Good morning. -[Rijkers] Good morning!
Hello!
[in Spanish] Did you study at home? [in English] No practicing?
Uh-uh. Nothing.
[Rijkers, in English] We're gonna play a game.
So I want you to think, kind of talk through a timeline.
How is the United States changing, looking at this map?
translation.ko: 미국이 어떻게 변했는지 이 지도를 보면서 얘기해보죠

translation.en: So, what area becomes part of the United States first,
translation.ko: 어느 지역이 최초로 미국의 영토가 됐나요?

translation.en: and then what next?
I'll give you a few minutes to talk about this in your groups.
translation.ko: 조원들과 몇 분간 얘기할 시간을 드릴게요

translation.en: [woman] So, originally, this was the first states.
And that was part of the United States, but not yet states.
What about Texas, it was, um, independent?
[Rijkers] It used to be part of Mexico, and then it was independent, -exactly. Yeah. -Okay.
[in Spanish] Mexico was this big, and now it's like this.
All of California was Mexico.
All of this was Mexico.
-[Fanny] Why did you let them take it? -[woman] It was a Mexican president.
translation.ko: "영토 획득 1776년~1886년" - 왜 넘겼죠? - 멕시코 대통령이 그랬어요

translation.en: -[Fanny] He sold it or what? -Yes.
How much did he take from that sale?
[woman, in English] Louisiana is so big.
The original are just these ones, 13.
The original, it is too small, right?
-[woman] Yes, it's small. -[Rijkers] Where's New York?
I also can't reach. It's over there.
Where's the Mississippi River?
The different areas became part of the United States at different times.
translation.ko: 각 지역은 다른 시기에 각각 미국의 영토가 됐어요

translation.en: Louisiana Purchase, that doubled the size of the United States.
translation.ko: 루이지애나 구입은 미국의 영토를 두 배로 늘렸죠

translation.en: But eventually, Native Americans were forcibly removed from their lands.
translation.ko: 하지만 아메리카 원주민들은 강제로 고향을 떠나야 했어요

translation.en: After Florida, what became part of the United States next?
translation.ko: 플로리다 다음에 미국이 된 곳은 어디죠?

translation.en: -[woman] Texas. -[Rijkers] Texas. Yeah.
What becomes part of the United States next?
-[man] Oregon. -[Rijkers] Oregon Country.
Yeah, now it's now Califor-- The state of California, part of it.
[Fanny, in Spanish] I was always very impressed
with the tenacity of those first immigrants.
translation.ko: 초기 이민자들의 끈기가 "1848년 멕시코 할양지" 매우 인상적이었어요

translation.en: How they had to struggle to establish themselves here.
translation.ko: 이곳에 뿌리내리기 위해 힘겹게 투쟁한 과정들이요

translation.en: I am Venezuelan in origin.
I began to work as a typist.
I went from secretary
to section manager, to department manager, to division manager,
to line manager, to general section director,
until I reached the position of bank president
and, subsequently, Minister of Agriculture.
Everything changed when a tyrant
ruined the economy of the country.
Venezuelans had never been immigrants, never.
Venezuelans would go on vacations,
and we would return to Venezuela,
selling our leftover US dollars.
Now, there are more than four million Venezuelans
outside of their country.
Families destroyed, families separated.
That is Venezuela.
So I decided to write a book
about the political, social, economic, and moral situation
translation.ko: 베네수엘라의 정치적, 사회적, 경제적 도덕적 현실에 관해서요

translation.en: in Venezuela.
translation.ko: 정치적, 사회적, 경제적 도덕적 현실에 관해서요

translation.en: We won’t be puppets
managed by President Hugo Chávez.
translation.ko: 우고 차베스 대통령의 꼭두각시로 살지 않을 겁니다

translation.en: [voice-over] That was the tipping point, because the police came after me.
translation.ko: 그게 인생의 분기점이 됐죠 경찰이 절 쫓기 시작했거든요

translation.en: And it was a truly terrible moment,
because I knew they were criminals, and if I said or did anything,
translation.ko: 그들은 범죄자였고 제가 그들 심기를 건드리면

translation.en: it could have deadly consequences for me.
[Dipna] I entered on a tourist visa.
I could come and go.
But after 9/11, they changed the visa system,
and that visa no longer functioned.
So I no longer had the possibility of changing that visa
translation.ko: 하지만 비자의 종류를 바꾸는 것도 불가능했죠

translation.en: because I no longer had anything in Mexico.
So that’s when I decided to no longer leave this country.
translation.ko: 그래서 이 나라를 떠나지 않기로 했어요

translation.en: Yes.
Okay, what’s the address?
Until finally, my son, when he turned 21,
he petitioned...
for my residency.
Sometimes I have felt frustrated by some people’s attitudes.
translation.ko: 가끔 사람들의 태도에 속이 상할 때가 있어요

translation.en: Recently, someone told us to stop speaking Spanish.
translation.ko: 최근엔 누가 제게 스페인어를 쓰지 말라고 했죠

translation.en: They said we shouldn’t speak Spanish on the bus,
that we should speak English.
It’s a very difficult experience.
You have to be really strong.
You learn how to leave your loneliness aside
and push yourself to try to get ahead for my sons.
[Rijkers, in English] What do you see here?
-[woman] Slave auction. -[woman 2] One woman...
Donna, you said right away slave auction.
How do we know that is what's happening?
-Public auction. -It says "sales."
-"Great sale." -[Rijkers] "Great Sale."
"Great sale of horses, cattle, Negroes and other farm stock
translation.ko: ''오늘 공개 경매에선 말, 소, 검둥이를 비롯한'

translation.en: this day at public auction."
[Rijkers] What else? What is he wearing?
-[woman] Just casual kind of clothes. -[woman 2] Mm-hmm.
-What kind of shoes is he wearing? -[group] No shoes.
[Rijkers] But the woman also doesn't wear shoes.
What about the woman? Have we come to a consensus?
Have we agreed on what her role is in all this?
translation.ko: 이 여자의 역할에 관해 모두 동의하는 의견이 있나요?

translation.en: [Fanny] She looks worried, because probably she's thinking
that the boys are going to be taken from her.
[Rijkers] Yeah, that was a very, um... -Worry. -...real possibility
for many families, that they would be taken apart.
That some family members would be sold to one person
translation.ko: 가족 중 한 명은 이 사람한테 팔리고

translation.en: and others to another, and they would be separated. Mm-hmm.
translation.ko: 다른 한 명은 저 사람한테 팔려서요

translation.en: [in Spanish] The slaves they brought over
were essential in building the foundation of this country.
translation.ko: 미국의 초석을 세우는 데 아주 중요한 역할을 했어요

translation.en: Sometimes, I think of everything they’ve gone through.
translation.ko: 그들이 겪은 일을 종종 생각하곤 해요

translation.en: Lots of suffering.
[Fanny] This is a multicolored country.
They came as slaves, but that contributed
to the melting pot that this beautiful country is.
translation.ko: 인종의 용광로인 이 아름다운 나라에 기여했죠

translation.en: [in English] So through art, John Rodgers showed...
Well, he was political through his art,
showing how horrible slavery was.
That families were being torn apart
and that people were being treated like animals. Right?
They literally say they are like other animals.
translation.ko: 실제로 가축과 함께 거래된다고 쓰여 있죠

translation.en: A major issue that led to the Civil War was slavery, as we can see here.
translation.ko: 여기서 볼 수 있듯이 노예제는 남북 전쟁의 주요 원인이었어요

translation.en: Name one problem that led to the Civil War.
translation.ko: 남북 전쟁을 야기한 한 가지 문제가 뭐죠?

translation.en: [group] Slavery.
Who lived in America before the Europeans arrived?
translation.ko: 유럽인이 오기 전에 아메리카엔 누가 살고 있었죠

translation.en: [group] Native Americans.
[Rijkers] What did the Emancipation Proclamation do?
[group] Free the slaves.
So, thank you all for coming. See you next week.
-Have a great week. -[woman] You too.
-[woman 2] Thank you. -[Rijkers] Mm-hmm.
[Fanny, in Spanish] This is the First Lady of the Republic,
this is the wife of the President of Congress, and this is me.
translation.ko: 이 사람은 국회 의장의 부인 이게 저예요

translation.en: This is a small part of the materials I presented when I applied for asylum.
translation.ko: 이건 망명을 신청할 때 제가 제출한 서류의 일부죠

translation.en: And this is the book that almost got me hanged.
translation.ko: 바로 이 책 때문에 교수형을 당할 뻔했어요

translation.en: [man] Fanny Bello writes a book.
translation.ko: 파니 베요는 한 권의 책을 썼습니다

translation.en: It is a letter to President Chávez.
It's called Letter to a Falling Chávez.
[Fanny] I was permanently fighting
against the government of Chávez.
What’s the message you want to send to the president, if he reads your book?
translation.ko: 이 책을 통해 대통령에게 하고 싶은 말은 무엇이었죠?

translation.en: I hope he reconsiders.
Specifically, in one chapter, I tell him
that he should pray the "Confiteor" with conviction.
translation.ko: 자기 죄를 뉘우치며 기도해야 한다고 생각해요

translation.en: If we don’t react to this mess,
we will end up being a franchise, and the owner will be Hugo Chávez.
translation.ko: 우린 우고 차베스가 주인인 체인점으로 전락하게 될 거예요

translation.en: [voice-over] They arrived in the morning
with guns in their hands, and soon the gun was at my head.
translation.ko: 총을 들고 나타났고 제 머리에 총을 겨눴죠

translation.en: They broke my computer,
threw me to the ground, tied me up, and killed my dog.
translation.ko: 절 땅에 내동댕이치고 절 묶고 제 개를 죽였어요

translation.en: They said they were doing this
to stop me from publishing propaganda.
translation.ko: 제 선전물의 출판을 막기 위해서라고 했죠

translation.en: And after that, well, I had to leave the country.
translation.ko: 그 일이 있은 후 베네수엘라를 떠나야 했어요

translation.en: I was afraid that they were going to put me in prison,
because the book hit them hard.
I came through the Colombian border,
I flew to Bogota, and from there to here.
THE AGRICULTURAL LIE
Chávez ruined the economy of the country.
In Venezuela, people are actually dying of hunger.
translation.ko: 베네수엘라에선 진짜로 사람들이 굶어 죽고 있죠

translation.en: [man] Who are we?
[all] Venezuela!
[Fanny] Long live Venezuela!
I am fighting now, and I will fight when I become a citizen.
translation.ko: 전 싸우고 있고 시민이 돼서도 싸울 겁니다 "베네수엘라는 민주주의의 회복을 원한다"

translation.en: Fighting to set Venezuela free from the present tyranny.
-[man, in English] Who are we? -[all] Venezuela!
-[man] What do we want? -[all] Freedom!
[Rijkers] I want to look at another image, so if you take one and pass.
translation.ko: 다른 그림을 보죠 한 장을 갖고 뒤로 전달해주세요

translation.en: And some here...
Yeah, if you help those to the back as well.
[woman] Look at all their faces.
[woman 2] Anti-low wages.
[Rijkers] So, I heard a lot of great reactions to this.
Yeah. All right, so, again, so...
What are the people doing in this-- in this image?
translation.ko: 이 그림 속에서 사람들은 뭘 하고 있죠?

translation.en: -[woman] Building a wall. -[Rijkers] Building a wall?
[woman] Anti-Chinese wall.
What does that mean, if they're building an anti-Chinese wall?
translation.ko: 반중국인 벽을 만드는 건 뭘 뜻할까요?

translation.en: -[woman] They don't like the Chinese. -Mm-hmm.
They don't want them to come in. Who are the people building this wall?
translation.ko: 입국을 반대하는 거죠 벽을 만드는 사람들은 누구죠?

translation.en: [woman] The other immigrants.
[Rijkers] Other immigrants!
-Immigrants. -Other immigrants.
That's the same as today.
[Rijkers] How is it similar today?
They're gonna build, like, a-- a wall.
Mexico. From Mexico.
And they talk about all those things from the people.
translation.ko: 요즘 하는 이야기들도 이 벽에 쓰인 것과 같아요

translation.en: -The same thing. -[Rijkers] Mm-hmm.
[Dipna] They want the best of the, uh, each country,
translation.ko: 그들은 각 국가에서 가장 좋은 걸 가져가면서

translation.en: but they don't want the people, just the products from it.
translation.ko: 사람들은 원치 않죠 생산물만 취하길 원해요

translation.en: They just want the product, yeah.
They benefit.
They benefit from them.
-History repeats. -[group] Yeah.
[Dagoberto, in Spanish] When you talk about asbestos, people panic.
translation.ko: 석면 얘기를 하면 사람들은 경기를 일으키죠

translation.en: There always has to be someone who does the work that they don’t want to do.
translation.ko: 그들이 하기 싫은 일을 할 사람이 늘 필요합니다

translation.en: That was one of the eligible jobs
to get the papers.
My boss told me, "Okay, we have to go and clean the Twin Towers."
translation.ko: 어느 날 상사가 무역 센터를 치우러 가야 한다고 하더군요

translation.en: I hadn't really grasped what had happened.
The scope of what had happened.
When I got there, wow.
[Alexandra] He worked there for one year.
I worked for about three months there.
We don’t know what can happen to us in the future.
translation.ko: 우리 미래에 어떤 일이 생길지 몰랐죠

translation.en: [Dagoberto] I got asthma after that.
I wasn’t asthmatic before, and now I have it.
translation.ko: 원랜 없었는데 그때 이후 생긴 거죠

translation.en: [Alexandra] We didn’t know how bad this was.
translation.ko: 우린 그게 얼마나 나쁜 건지 몰랐어요

translation.en: We couldn’t imagine what was in the air.
translation.ko: 공기에 뭐가 있는지 상상하지 못했던 거죠

translation.en: We were caught up...
in having work
and being useful.
In a few years, we can end up sick from that.
translation.ko: 그런데 몇 년 후에 그것 때문에 병에 걸렸죠

translation.en: We can die, and isn’t that dying for this country?
translation.ko: 죽을지도 모르는데 그럼 순국하는 거 아닌가요?

translation.en: To help with that tragedy?
We think that we’ve earned the right to become citizens.
translation.ko: 우린 시민권을 취득할 자격이 있다고 생각해요

translation.en: -Right? -[Dagoberto] Yes.
[woman, in English] Say "unemployed" and fill out your address.
Have you ever been involved with any of the following:
translation.ko: 다음과 같은 일에 관여한 적 있나요?

translation.en: genocide,
torture, killing,
badly hurting a person on purpose...
Have you ever been arrested, charged with a crime,
-handcuffed by a police officer? -[man] No. No.
No. Got it, all right.
[woman] Were you ever a member of, or did you ever serve in
or help, or participate in-- in any way in any kind of military group?
translation.ko: 어떤 방식으로든 도움을 준 적이 있나요?

translation.en: We'll see if you need any of that.
If you traveled a lot or had a lot of jobs,
translation.ko: 여행을 많이 했거나 많은 직업을 거쳤다면

translation.en: -so we'll check on that. -[man] Can I have those papers?
translation.ko: - 확인해봐야 해요 - 그 서류 좀 주시겠어요?

translation.en: Thanks.
[Alexandra, in Spanish] We are very afraid that the person who is leading us now
translation.ko: 우린 현재의 지도자가 우릴 끔찍한 곳으로 인도할까 봐

translation.en: could lead us to something terrible.
Despite what’s happening now,
I think there are many good people who want change.
They say that it's always darkest
before the dawn.
[Rijkers] It's really powerful to see why people are coming to this country
translation.ko: 사람들이 이곳에 와서 이 나라의 일부가 되려는 이유를

translation.en: and why they want to be a part of this country.
I think the United States government decided to include questions
translation.ko: 전 미국 정부가 노예제와 남북 전쟁에 관해

translation.en: about slavery, about the Civil War,
because that is American history,
and if you don't understand the past
and you want to become a part of this country,
you don't understand the present.
[Rijkers] Um, so...
what did Martin Luther King Jr. do?
translation.ko: 마틴 루서 킹 주니어가 한 일이 뭐죠?

translation.en: -[group] Fight for Civil Rights. -[Rijkers] Fought for Civil Rights.
translation.ko: - 시민권을 위한 투쟁요 - 시민권을 위해 투쟁했죠

translation.en: We can also say that he worked for equality for all American people.
translation.ko: 모든 미국인의 평등을 위해 노력했다고 답할 수도 있어요

translation.en: Yeah.
I'm going to show you a video of a part of a speech that he gave.
How long will it take?
Somebody’s asking,
"How long will prejudice blind the visions of men?"
How long? Not long.
Because the arc of the moral universe is long,
but it bends toward justice.
-How long? Not long! -[man] Not long.
[in Spanish] Everyone has a right to life, liberty,
-religion... -To vote.
[Dagoberto] There wasn’t justice at that time.
To have someone else oppress you
-is not right. -[Alexandra] Forcefully, right?
[in Chinese] As humans, we are never perfect. We have our shortcomings.
translation.ko: 우린 인간이기에 완벽하지 않죠 모두 결점이 있어요

translation.en: America has its shortcomings.
However...
America’s political system, belief system...
are trying to overcome these shortcomings.
translation.ko: 그 결점을 극복하기 위해 노력하고 있습니다

translation.en: Its political system is moving towards the right direction.
translation.ko: 미국의 정치 체제는 올바른 방향으로 가고 있죠

translation.en: [in Spanish] For things to move forward and get better, someone has to suffer.
translation.ko: 진보와 개선을 위해선 누군가가 고통받아야 합니다

translation.en: At that time, they’re the ones who suffered.
[Rijkers, in English] You understand why he became such an important leader
translation.ko: 영상을 보니까 루서 킹이 중요한 지도자였던

translation.en: of that movement, because he was a great speaker.
This was such a long fight,
and there were so many things we couldn't discuss today,
translation.ko: 오늘 미처 하지 못한 이야기도 정말 많아요

translation.en: there were so many ways in which African Americans
were fighting for equality and still are today.
translation.ko: 평등을 쟁취하려 해왔고 지금도 그러고 있어요

translation.en: The final thing we have to do is just cover some of the questions.
translation.ko: 마지막으로 할 일은 질문을 살펴보는 거예요

translation.en: What movement tried to end racial discrimination?
translation.ko: 어떤 운동이 인종 차별을 끝내려 했죠?

translation.en: -[group] Civil Rights. -[Rijkers] Civil Rights Movement.
So "civil" means "of the people."
[woman] Jian Zhang.
[Zhang, in Chinese] I came to the US in 1999
to do my doctoral study in physics.
And now, I’ve been accepted as a member of the society.
translation.ko: 그리고 이제 이 사회의 일원이 됐습니다

translation.en: I feel that all my years
of admiring America's value system have finally been valued.
translation.ko: 존경하며 보내온 시간이 마침내 인정받은 것 같아요

translation.en: All my years of yearning its value system have been valued.
translation.ko: 미국의 가치 체계를 갈망하며 보내온 시간이요

translation.en: I am now part of the American society.
[man, in English] Behind me, you see the eagle,
the symbol of the United States of America.
We are a beautiful and substantive and powerful nation
translation.ko: 우리는... "윌리엄 F 쿤츠 지방 법원 판사" 아름답고 독립적이며 강한 국가입니다

translation.en: because of what you have contributed
and because of what you will contribute.
Just what is this sacred liberty
that must lie in the hearts of men and women?
translation.ko: "루스 베이더 긴즈버그 미국 대법원 판사" 이 신성한 자유는 무엇일까요?

translation.en: The spirit of liberty is the spirit
which is not too sure it is right.
The spirit of liberty
is the spirit which seeks to understand
the minds of other men and women without bias.
May the spirit of liberty be your beacon
as you play your part in helping to achieve
a more perfect union.
[in Spanish] This country has a history of struggle
for all of the rights that are enjoyed now.
translation.ko: 우리가 향유하는 권리는 모두 투쟁의 산물이에요

translation.en: When you’re a citizen, you can vote, you can run for office.
translation.ko: 시민은 투표할 수 있고 선거에 나갈 수 있어요

translation.en: This is a country of immigrants.
Who is not an immigrant in this country?
translation.ko: 이 나라에 이민자가 아닌 사람이 있나요?

translation.en: [in English] Albania, Algeria, Argentina,
Australia, Burkina Faso, Canada, China, Denmark,
Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Georgia.
We're all from somewhere else.
translation.ko: 우리는 모두 다 다른 나라에서 왔습니다

translation.en: We are a nation made strong
translation.ko: 우리 국가는 여러분 같은 사람들 덕분에

translation.en: by people like you.
People who have traveled long distances
translation.ko: 자신과 가족의 더 나은 삶을 찾아서

translation.en: overcome great obstacles,
all to provide a better life
for themselves and their families.
Please, raise your right hand and repeat after me.
translation.ko: 오른손을 들고 제 말을 따라 해주세요

translation.en: -"I hereby declare..." -[crowd] I hereby declare.
-"...on oath..." -[crowd] On oath.
-"...that I absolutely..." -[crowd] That I absolutely.
-"...and entirely..." -[crowd] And entirely.
-"...renounce and abjure..." -[crowd] Renounce and abjure.
-"...all allegiance and fidelity..." -[crowd] All allegiance and fidelity.
[Ginsburg] "To any foreign prince..."
[crowd] To any foreign prince.
-"...State, or sovereignty..." -[crowd] State, or sovereignty.
"And that I take this obligation freely..."
[crowd] And that I take this obligation freely.
-"So help me God." -[Judge Kuntz] "So help me God."
[woman] Yay, we did it!
